enhanced_description: Pad Thai is Thailand's most iconic dish, a perfect harmony of sweet, sour, and salty flavors wrapped around silky rice noodles. Born from a 1930s nationalism campaign, this stir-fried noodle dish has become the global ambassador of Thai cuisine. The secret lies in the tamarind-based sauce and the wok hei (breath of the wok) that only comes from expert high-heat cooking.

detailed_ingredients.name: Rice Noodles (Sen Lek)
detailed_ingredients.purpose: The foundation - flat rice noodles that soak up all the flavors

detailed_ingredients.name: Tamarind Paste
detailed_ingredients.purpose: Provides the signature tangy-sweet flavor that defines authentic Pad Thai

detailed_ingredients.name: Palm Sugar
detailed_ingredients.purpose: Adds caramel sweetness that balances the sour tamarind

detailed_ingredients.name: Dried Shrimp
detailed_ingredients.purpose: Adds umami depth and authentic flavor

cooking_method.steps_overview: Pad Thai is all about timing and technique. Each ingredient enters the wok at precisely the right moment. The noodles must be soft but not mushy, the egg ribboned through, and everything tossed with enough force to combine but gentle enough not to break the noodles.
cooking_tips: Soak noodles in room temperature water, not hot - prevents mushiness
Keep ingredients moving constantly in the wok
Push ingredients up the sides of the wok to create cooking zones
The sauce should caramelize slightly on the noodles
Add bean sprouts at the very end for crunch

cultural_significance.origin_story: Created in the 1930s as part of Prime Minister Plaek Phibunsongkhram's nation-building campaign. He wanted a national dish that would unify Thailand and reduce rice consumption during World War II. The name literally means 'Thai-style stir-fry'.
cultural_significance.cultural_importance: Pad Thai represents Thai culinary diplomacy. It's often the first Thai dish foreigners try and has become synonymous with Thai cuisine globally. In Thailand, the quality of a cook is often judged by their Pad Thai.
